history.content:
61B and 70 are both challenging classes, but for very different reasons.
61B is very coding intensive but its definitely a good idea to take it with hug over hilfinger if you're concerned about workload, but you will still spend many hours crying over project 2 (hug is teaching next semester, and project 2 is the hilfinger-esque mega-project.). You will also get a lot more practical knowledge about coding in that class than 70. You also get some kool projects to show off. 
However, if you're a math god / proof inclined, you may want to take 70 instead. It doesn't require any coding experience but it is extremely mathematically rigourous and you will spend many hours crying over problem sets. After completing 70 you'll be happy because all your classes after won't seem nearly as hard or perplexing. It will teach you how to get through difficult problems. 
TLDR i strongly recommend 61B with Hug unless you're craving a strong theoretical understanding of very hard problems.

Also, I took CS10 spring of my sophomore year and decided to go the cs route after that class and had no prior experience coding. Currently a junior and declaring this semester. If you have any other questions or just want to chat about it feel free to send me an email at ncatranis@berkeley.edu

children.subject:
I was in a very similar situation in terms of swapping from Econ/Haas to CS.

Econ 101A is a fairly light workload class 61B assumes a lot of knowledge from 61A in my experience whereas 70 does not so I think taking 61A and 70 simultaneously would be better.
+1 to taking 61B with hug, though 61A and 61B in combination is doable depending on the amount of programming experience that you have!
I heard from someone a few years ago that you couldn't double major with ORMS. Not sure if this is still true, but figured you may want to look into it!

Hello, I'm a new transfer student just looking over past piazza posts. Im enrolled in cs61a over the summer. I do have some intro to data structure(in c++) and intro java course taken from my community college. If you dont mind me asking, how was the workload takikg 61b and 70 together over summer? I've also taken intro to discrete mathematics. Would you recommend it? How hard is it to pull off A's in both. If i dont take 61a and 70 together this summer, ill be taking 61b(with prof. Hilfinger) and 70 together over fall. Thank you in advance!

I would not recommend it.

Keep in mind that this was my "5th" semester at Cal, so for someone used to the rigor of Cal courses, I still found it extremely difficult. 9am-11pm, all work except for meal breaks, Monday to Friday. A lot of work on the weekends too. In the end, I pulled off A's in both, but it was a lot of work and I did not have a fun summer at all. 

You have an advantage in that you've taken some data structures and discrete mathematics, so it will be more doable for you. But keep in mind that part of CS70 is also Probability, which you may or may not have learned. Discrete mathematics is only about 1/3 of the course.

Overall, I would recommend taking 61A and getting a feel of how classes at Cal are, and maybe a breadth requirement! Perhaps an AC course or something that fulfills your R&C requirement. Many students choose to do 61B and 70 in the Fall and it is very doable.

Good luck! :)
I was in the same position, I took 61B and 70 over the summer, declaring at the end of the summer. Let me know if you have any questions.

history.content: I'm a current sophomore that was pre-business/ORMS and is now intending to switch into ORMS/CS. I'll be declaring ORMS next semester and thus will be taking 61A(A pre-req that can be taken after declaring). I've always had an interest in CS but did not pursue it due to my business track, but I've decided I really want to pursue it now. I've taken CS 10 and Math 53, and am currently enrolled in math 54 and Data 8. I'd like to declare by the end of summer, so I need to take either 61B or 70 concurrently with 61A in the spring in order to do so. What would be the best combination? In addition to these two CS classes, I'll be taking Econ 101A and most likely a Decal, as I know the workload is quite high. Thank you very much!
history.subject: Decided to switch to CS fairly late, best combination of classes to declare on time?
